div.p:
☞The Berlin papers received by the City of
Baltimore, contain the following very curious and
characteristic card from Baron Humboldt:

“Suffering beneath the pressure of a still increas-
ing correspondence, amounting to between sixteen
hundred and two thousand communications per
annum, and embracing letters, printed pamphlets
on matters with which I am wholly unacquainted,
manuscripts concerning which my opinion is desir-
ed, projects for emigration and colonizing, the send-
ing of models, machines and natural curiosities, re-
quests of contributions and collections of auto-
graphs, offers to take charge of my domestic con-
cerns, to cheer and enliven me, &c., &c., I must
again publicly urge all persons having my welfare
at heart to exert their influence in my behalf, that
individuals in both continents may no longer busy
themselves with my person and make of my house
an intelligence office; and that I be allowed, in the
declining state of my physical and mental powers,
to enjoy some rest and leisure to attend to my du-
ties. May this cry for relief, which I utter with
much reluctance and after reflection, not meet an
unfriendly interpretation!
“Alexander Von Humboldt.”
